author: Lus
review: You can actually feel yourself riding the Horizon :)P.S. The general rule of thumb with Forza games is the "premium edition" is the way to go because it actually saves your money in the long run and you get pretty much everything in the game

author: Nobody
review: So let me preface this with the fact that I have owned every Forza title since the original Forza was released on the original Xbox. This will likely be my last Forza Title ever purchased.For a major title game by a major studio to have THIS MANY release issues is just straight embarrassing.  The game is virtually unplayable in online mode. constant disconnects and server side issues (oh, whats that, youve racked up a 100k skill score?? random server interrupt that makes your car act like it hit a wall and lose all your skill points). The game does funny things in solo mode too. Theres a free house with the VIP pack, you "buy it", access it, log out, and when you log back in you no longer own it, but when you go back it says "free with vip" so you click it again and it tells you that you already own it, but you can not access it.... Sometimes when you log back in youre in a different car than you were when you logged out (usually back in whatever car you started with). But the worst part of it is, through all the hype over new this and new that, this game feel, looks, and plays, EXACTLY like FH4. I mean seriously; races are named the same and have the same general layout, many of the barn finds are the same as they were in FH4. In fact, some of the cars from FH4 have LESS customizable options in FH5 than they did in FH4. But oooohhh, here, put a 10 speed transmission and paint the brake calipers; apparently that quantifies as 'unforeseen levels of customization'.The next Gen graphics are good, assuming you have something powerful enough to display that high of detail, otherwise, it looks the same... And in typical Horizon fashion, you start off with several million dollars worth of cars, and have no real challenge as, whether your racing online against other players, or solo against drivatars of those players, Horizon has never been about finding the best line and winning the race through skill; its about never lifting off the throttle and using the other cars as bumper guards to get to the end and win.Theres so much more that this game lacks in but if youve read this far youve likely read enough. I will keep playing (mostly because I wasted $100 on this game), but until the devs either fix a TON of stuff, or this game goes to 70% off, dont buy it.

author: gpu lis
review: FH5 is basically an improvement over FH4 in every single way. Playground Games have taken user feedback from FH4, its 2 expansions and its live program and implemented it in FH5 to improve the experience. Looking at FH4, it's very likely that this game will also be supported for around the same time. The visuals have received a significant improvement over FH4 with the inclusion of higher fidelity car models and world geometry made with photogrammetry. The new Global Illumination system provides more accurate lighting in most conditions. The 12K skies captured on location are back in FH4 with 10 times the sky presets available in FH4 providing a wide variety conditions to drive in. Ray Tracing is available only in Forzavista but can be enabled in gameplay with a Cheat Engine hack. Notably with all these improvements over FH4, the spec requirements are still relatively modest with the game performing well even on dated hardware without sacrificing too much on quality.SFX have received a big improvement over FH4 with higher quality recordings as well as a greater number of them providing a lot more unique sounds to the wide selection of cars. Car upgrades now affect the sound of a car, meaning cars sound a lot more unique as every player customises their car differently. Ray traced audio has also been implemented; bouncing sound off of the environment (tress, rocks, mountains etc.) to provide realistic echoes and low tones. One of the important features of any Horizon game is the soundtrack and PG have curated an excellent selection of tracks along with many original tracks made in collaboration with artists they've worked with in the past specifically for the game. All the radio stations from FH4 are back with Timeless being rebranded to Eterna.The handling model is the most important aspect of any racing game. Horizon has always followed the simcade approach, providing simplicity to casual players and complexity to experienced players. FH5 improves on the handling model by making the cars feel more weighty and responsive and the new changes to the suspension model makes it easier to drive off road. Wheel support has also received a big improvement, adding support for more wheels. However hand over hand steering is still missing. Driving modes and raising/lowering the roof in convertibles in freeroam has been added, however currently the feature is limited to very few cars and hopefully the number will increase in time.The new weather events in the form of Tropical Storms and Dust Storms make the world feel more Dynamic and add interesting challenges to the gameplay by affecting visibility and traction. These storms can be seen from a distance and players can choose to drive into them or avoid them. The same is true with the Seasons system. Previously in FH4, players were forced to play in snow or rain depending on the season. However, in FH5, snow and rain are limited to certain parts of the map allowing players to opt out of them.Expanding on Blueprints and Super 7 from FH4, the new Events Lab feature gives even more control over custom game modes and props to users allowing for even greater user generated content to be made. Events Lab allows players to set their own game rules and create actions using If-Then type actions .The campaign is now called Horizon Adventure and adds a lot more progression compared to previous games. Players must earn accolades which are like mini achievements for completing various actions in the game which then unlock points that can be redeemed on various activities that further the campaign. The way that it's been set up allows players to earn accolades from any activity they liked doing and are not forced to do activities they don't like. Accolades provide incentive for players to play the game in different ways and explore activities they usually don't indulge in. The accolades leaderboard encourages competition amidst players to rise the ranks.The season system returns from FH4 with a slight redesign to adapt to the new location. The traditional seasons, Spring, Summer, Autumn, and Winter, are now simplified and called Hot, Wet, Storm, and Dry. The festival playlist which ties in to the week long seasons is back with a few tweaks and the promise of including user generated content and making more substantial changes to the game world such as the world makeover for Christmas, adding snowmen and presents to smash around the world. Online Adventure is now called the Horizon Open and does not feature ranked racing (might change in the future). Eliminator has been added into Horizon Open, which is the battle royale game mode first introduced in FH4 and quickly became the most played online game mode. Horizon Tour is a new game mode which involves Team vs Team racing against AI. The extremely long loading times in FH4 sadly carry over to this game along with the inability to mute in-game voice chat. Whether the new handling model changes makes AWD and meta car builds less over powered will only be made clear with time. Forzathon Live events from FH4 have now been renamed to Horizon Arcade with some changes. The changes made to Arcade has made it unplayable as the lack of participating players combined with the small time limit and big score requirements makes completing the event almost impossible. As of the time of writing this review players are expecting connection issues which should be fixed soon. The game has 3 editions on offer- Standard, Deluxe and Premium. Standard and Premium offer the best value with Deluxe only adding the Car pass over the standard edition. If you're new to the franchise, the standard edition offers the best value. If you're a Horizon veteran and know you're going to put in a ton of hours in, Premium could save you some money on DLCs you'll end up buying anyway if you bought the Standard edition.FH5 can be seen as a refinement of the formula that worked so well for past Horizons. One of the best handling models in any arcade style racing game, breathtaking visuals and a soundtrack to complement it. Mexico as the new location is a great choice, providing a wide variety of environments combined with the new weather events adding more dynamicity. With this being Playground Games' 2nd live service program, and their history of listening to community feedback, the game is sure to improve over time and receive new and interesting content over its lifetime.tl;dr If you liked FH4, you'll love FH5. If you're new to Horizon games, this is a great one time experience even if you don't stick with the game but chances are you'll get addicted. Also skip the Deluxe edition.Update: This game deserved to be nominated for GOTY if not win the award.

After few days of gameplay here is my views on the gameOpen world â­â­â­â­â­Story â­â­â­â­Content â­â­â­â­â­Audio/video â­â­â­â­â­best racing game ever created to date. author: schweppestr
review: Currently arguably the best racing game on the market and the developers made a lot of improvements over Horizon 4. + The map is bigger and a lot more varied. There are deserts, canyons, jungles, beaches, a volcano etc. so it always feels exciting to explore.+ Vehicle sounds have been improved a lot and they change based on the upgrades you install.+ Hundreds of cars with huge variety. There is something for every taste, from JDM tuners to American muscles, SUVs and trucks to supercars.+ A lot of events to participate. There are the classic sprint and circuit road, rally and cross country races but you can also play drift races, a battle royal mode, player-made modes etc. or complete the story and open world challenges.+ Previously it was very hard to drive rear wheel drive cars without assists especially when they are upgraded to higher performance levels so people usually converted them to all wheel drive layout but it is much more comfortable now.+ The campaign is better than it is in Horizon 4. It was basically non-existent back then and the festival was present only at a small location. Now the festival atmosphere is better felt with different locations across the map.- In Horizon 4 you could select specific class and type of online races you wanted to join. For example you could choose "A class road races" if you didn't want other performance classes or rally and cross country races, but unless I am blind I don't see this option in this game, so you will always get a random class and type. The cons are nothing compared to the pros and how fun the game is so I definitely recommend.

Hated how I switched from Xbox to Steam and had to completly restart. I had nothing but an massively outdated unsold Porsche on the market, which I cant remove because its not on the same "plattform". You can feel its an arcade game. Its fun overall. But the time you spend in dont feel like it. I spen 80 hours on it and it feels like ive been 40-60 on it. But overall, a enjoyable game I can recommend if you have the money and the mentality to grind for nothingPositives:-Graphic-Photomode-Livery editor-"Story"-Missions-Very chill racing gameNegatives:-Takes alot of time-Your Data is lost when changing from Xbox to Steam-Car sounds tbh

author: Barrel
review: welcome to Forza Horizon Series, where you don't need to have any anxiety over fuel or repair costs, your virtual fans love you enough they drop cars to your garage like if it's some cheap fathers day socks, and theres no police to judge how awful you're driving, or getting you when you're stealing cars from random barns.

author: Bixnic
review: If you're on the fence of buying it... just do it. As someone who's played every Forza Motorsport game and Forza Horizon game, this is by far the most beautiful and polished the game has been. It's an absolutely stunning game and very well optimized, Mexico can't be beat. It is easily becoming my favorite map out of any of the Horizon games. There is more than enough things to do, earning money is rewarding, variety of races is endless especially when it comes to community blueprints and mini games. Music I'd say is good, not great. Pulse radio was always my go to now it seems like a pop station now, I find myself on Bass Arena now. Other stations are good lots of variety, there's something for everybody. The amount of cars and customization is one of the reasons why this is easily becoming my favorite Horizon game to date, endless cars. They've added more parts to add and customize, they listened to community and fixed the audio so I commend them for that. Final Rating: 9.5/10Only thing I continue to feel in the most recent Horizon Games is that there really isn't a campaign, well there is but doesn't feel like it. As they kinda just throw you in the world with 400 races and pretty much say "Do whatever you want" for me I miss the feeling of grinding for a purpose other than ranking up and buying every car I want which is nice but I want more out of it.

author: Ð¾Ð½_explÐ¾de
review: I'm not a huge Forza player (only played 4), but with 5 releasing on Steam I decided to give this one a shot with the full premium package. So far, I've had an awesome time with the game. There's little "progression" and the story is laughably bad, but thankfully that's not the point. It's all about taking whatever car you want and letting loose in Forza's open world. The best part is, you get to play however you'd like. Personally, I did all the cross-country and dirt events first and still, at 80+ hours in, haven't even touched the street racing. The soundtrack is pretty good, personally Hospital, Pulse and Bass Arena are what I cycle through. The only real complaint so far is the net-code and online issues. Still haven't made it past round 2 of a Horizon Arcade, so here's hoping that gets smoothed out soon. If you're a filthy-casual like me, or a hardcore sim engine-tuner, you can enjoy the game at your own leisure.edit: 12/7 Horizon Arcade has been adjusted to amount of players which is great, but still online issues have not been fixed.

author: jspirit1_266
review: This game is just a very good repeat of all the other forza games, 90% same cars, same short boring stories(no offense lol) and above average graphics. I liked forza horizon 4 alot, as the seasons where so beautiful, and the online experience racing on the highway or meeting friends was way easier. Alot of people would disagree with me on this but i wish forza horizon 5 had a smaller map..... Its harder to meet players on the open world experience than previous games.. And the online mini games are the same.They promised more customization with cars... But i didn't see a difference from FH4 for the most part in that category, but the cars do sound better, like WAY better. You know im a big fan of realism, and to be honest i really don't enjoy the map... The developers did a awesome job of highlighting the forest and desert areas(offroad), but the city and street life in nonexistent.... In forza horizon 4 there was more variety, you could fit in perfectly with a lambo in a upper class area of the city or drive a old beater in a rural road. Now its like im driving a 2 million dollar lambo through little village dirt roads to go to my little beach loft lmao like doesnt feel realistic. The developers only focused on the off road aspect of the game taking 80% of the map with mostly rural roads, then leave a little village for the streetlife and street races. If your a big fan of offroading and offroad races then you would probably like this.. But if your like me and like some need for speed action, or some nice city to rip up in a lambo... Then this game isnt for you. Theres alot of politics in this game too.... People getting banned for livery or the wrong stickers on their car, but cheaters not getting banned. The developers are slow to addressing issues with online cheating, but quick to ban anyone using "hate speech" and doing grey area petty things. I dont really care about these issues personally, but these issues seem to be getting worse with each game.Get this game on a sale, and try it out.... or theres always forza horizon 4 :)

author: Chqnces
review: First time getting back into the Horizon series since the first game back in 2012 and I am really enjoying this! The visuals are great, there's a ton of cars to choose from, lots to explore and different kinds of activities and races to do! Playing with friends is also easy to connect and fun. In terms of bugs, they do get extremely annoying. The main issue I am having is crashing after pressing start on the main menu. Alongside this, a narrator voice automatically comes on despite being off in the settings. 4 months since release and it's still not fixed??? Playground should at least start fixing these issues than adding more on top of it. Anti-aliasing can also use some work as it's still not looking good on extreme settings. I still have lots more to do, but it's been a decent experience so far. 9/10.

author: The Deep
review: If you like car games anywhere in the spectrum from pure arcade to light simulation, this game has something for you. If you like going fast in a straight line or round corners, or slow and sideways, this game has something for you. If you like car meets and taking photos of cars, this game has something for you. If you like tuning small details to get that little bit extra performance, that extra 1/10th of a second in the 1/4 mile, or to hold that drift angle a little longer, this game has something for you. If you like making and playing community content, this game has something for you. If you like driving with your friends online, or with complete strangers, this game has something for you. Go check it out. A lot quicker to get to the free roam part than Horizon 4, and currently less cars, but everything just feels better, on keyboard, controller, and wheel. 9/10.

author: Twiz
review: Forza Horizon 5 is like a Forza Horizon greatest hits album. A beautiful graphical display, apt social features, and a boat-load of exotic cars make the Forza Horizon festival everything it already was and more. The handling and fundamental mechanics remain unrivalled; the cars are still absolutely stunning; and as for Mexico as an environmentâ€¦ well, itâ€™s honestly a bit mind-blowing. Ultimately, itâ€™s hard to fault Forza Horizon 5 at all. Playground games have totally outdone themselves.Petrol-heads are in for a treat with this one.

author: enzym
review: Forza Horizon is since Horizon 2 one of my favourite franchises. I had high expectations and after 50 hours ive seen most parts of the game and can do a short review. For everyone who played Forza Horizon 4, it will feel like home if you first enter the new menu screen. There are some new features like the expeditions, but basically the game feels very similar to his predecessors. The difference between those games is the setting it takes place in. Every title has its very own feeling, because of the culture and the country its representing. In that case, Forza Horizon 5 is no exception.The map is bigger than everything we had before and the mexican style is implemented very well. There are many kinds of nature and scenery, like beautiful beaches, large fields, canyons or deserts with nearly white sand. The feeling of going on a holidaytrip to mexico just by playing the game is awesome. The world is beautiful made, with many details and some interesting secrets, the amount of cars is huge. Not that many new ones, but nearly everything we know is back. In terms of races you can choose between offroad- and classical onroadraces. Because of the beauty of the map you are going for some great tracks and with higher difficulty quite challenging races against the AI or friends. Other than that, you can do the typical drift zones, speed cameras or the ,,storys'' the game tells you. Those storys are a quite nice addition, which is representing the countrys culture but get boring very quick, cause the missions are very repetitive and the scenarios in my opinion are totally irrelevant. The first expedition into the jungle is sadly the only one, which stands out and was just awesome. Theres so much to do and you can choose what youre doing next or leaving out.But what would be Forza without the cars. Like i said, the selection is huge and nearly each one is great detailed, even the interior is realistic made. I love to spend hours in customizing my dream cars, set the rims i want, the colours, the grade of window tint, nearly everything is possible. Even the rims are licensed and some bodykits and spoilers too. In my opinion, its one of the best feelings in a videogame to build your car and drive it, while listening to your favourite music, through the beautiful scenery of the game. Hang out with your friends on the beach while watching the sunset, explore the awesome world cruising in your favourite car or race some other drivers. Its the feeling of a living world youre set in, a short trip to one of the most awesome places on earth. These things describe the best what Forza Horizon is to me. And thats exactly what Forza Horizon 5 takes you in. In the actual state the game has some negative aspects too. The AI is a bit inconsistent. Sometimes they let you overtake, while driving much slower or you loose the next race on the same difficulty, cause they are driving like on rails. Often you cant create a convoy or the game desyncs while in race. These things kill the awesome feeling i described in some parts, but the devs are working to fix those issues. In terms of performance the game is running fine. I can recommend this game to everyone who is interested in cars and/or racing. For me its the perfect mix between arcade (NFS) and simulation (AC). If there would be many games of this kind, which are as good as Forza Horizon, it wouldnt be that successful. Wait until the bugs get fixed and you are getting an awesome game.Thank you very much for reading and have a nice day.

author: teddy'
review: Nice arcade racing game, however it becomes boring after a while. Uninstalled today and will return once the new content will be there

author: Kurosaki
review: Oh boy, It's the 5th one in the series and my 2nd FH game. I really loved FH4 and so far really enjoying this one. The beauty and detail are unparalleled, the creativity by Playground games is what really shines throughout the series. They obviously know how to make a good racing game but they also know how to make a good game ( If you catch my drift), I was a non racing fan for the most part of my gaming life aside from the good ol NFS MW days but when I play a Forza Horizon game, I really find myself enjoying the different degrees of freedom it offers whilst remaining true to it's core.That being said, the steam version recently got an update to adress some issues which many of us have faced during the first two weeks following the launch. After the recent patch I did notice few stutters while first booting up the game then it dies down 30 secs later. The LOD and draw distance are still an issue even on Ultra atleast for me but looks great in Extreme but FPS crawls to 25. After the patch, the draw distance is slightly better but far from perfect. Also I'm using MSAA 4x and it kind of looks shimmery at times, I remember this being an issue in FH4 which was fixed eventually.The thing is they are still releasing updates for FH4 and fixed major visual bugs in FH4, so  I am confident that they are more than capable of fixing some draw distance and shimmering in the following patches.TLDR; The game has few visual bugs but they will be fixed very soon but if you have a low-mid end PC anyways and you prefer lowering your settings, you won't be disappointed how this game looks and runs on lower end hardware.

author: JPK
review: Buy Forza Horizon 4 - three times cheaper, more fun and polished. FH4 has more populated lobby and a lot more player interaction, 100 cars more, better UI and more interesting map.If you have 1000 hours in FH4 and want more of the same formula but slightly different, go ahead I guess, otherwise I'd stick to FH4, at least until FH5 is heavily discounted.FH5 still has many issues that predecessors had - devs seem to completely not care about fixing core mechanics of the game and rather spend time implementing features which are not that important - like opening car roofs, pronouns or sign language (to torment deaf people with terrible, cringeworthy story I imagine.Main cons:* AI still uses a completely different model of physics than the player, basically random car models on rails that never slide around, push you with great force and randomly decide between accelerating twice as fast as you and not using accelerator at all.* UI is worse than FH4 in many aspects, much more "consolized" and large - two cars in a garage column? Really?* Many bugs and issues still persist - for example, crappy auction house that is slow to use, lags and bids often fail for no reason.* Story reached new heights of cringe, especially with every other sentence being mix of english/spanish.* Lobby building seems to be much worse than FH4 - I logged into FH4 and saw 60 players on my map, here I never saw it past 15. This leads to a lot less interaction with other players, especially forzathon/arcade, you are lucky to have 1 or 2 other players doing it with you (there's also four happening at the same time, unlike single one in FH4).* Still not many visual tuning parts and wanting adjustable aero forcing you to use ugly spoiler on every car - please, just make adjustable aero some invisible checkbox.* No businesses* No ranked* Visual bugs and crashes that I don't experience in FH4For pros, car sounds are better, a few more performance upgrade options.

author: PublicRaptor
review: Its like the white bread of racing games, it looks great but has no flavor.

author: Ary
review: Improving over an already fantastic game, Forza Horizon 5 is hands-down the best in the genre. Pros:â€¢  A graphical masterpiece - The Mexico set up is beautiful <3 with all the different biomes it has on offer, you will drive around aimlessly admiring the beauty around you.â€¢ Much needed improvement in the 'Sounds' department - The upgrades/modifications changes the exhaust note, so tweak it to your liking!â€¢ Improved driving - I completed all the drift zones with 3 stars rating for the first time in a Forza game!â€¢ Your character actually has a voice now, a subtle but a welcome change.â€¢ Tyre smokes! You will love this.â€¢ Other gameplay changes like event organization, more trailblazers etcâ€¢ Optimized enough for my trusty old 1070Ti to run it on everything maxed at 1080p at around 60 FPS.â€¢ Steam version is not broken like FH4Cons:* Horizon Arcade. What was supposed to be a fun 10 mins like Forzathon Live, became a grind. Even after 2 weeks, it is not doable.â€¢ Some connection issues in between, which the devs have already said they are working to fix it; so may have already been solved.â€¢ Radio maybe? I really enjoyed song selection in FH4 more.â€¢ Not regionally priced like FH4 If you liked previous Forza Horzion games, you will definitely have a good time with FH5.

author: Kai
review: Microsoft pulled the classic bait and switch and backed out of valve regional prices, ~tripled in most regions. I do not recommend spending that amount for this, its not worth it. Give it a try on the pass first. If you get FH4 and FH3 ultimates together on a sale you would have almost the exact same game as this, better maps and more terrain and weather diversity and still have some money left over instead of buying this broken mess.*Mexico is underwhelming, uninteresting and boring.*Not sure if its the location itself but Mexico is by far the worst looking Horizon map, not sure what they were going for, realistic I guess but ended up with dull. Compared to FH3 and FH4 the visual presentation difference is night and day, they still look better somehow. To be clear, the textures are better, models are highly detailed and the number of props in the map are significantly more than the previous games but they just don't look good.*There are several technical and online issues atm, crashes and bugs. Same online problems as before, loading and sync. Haven't come across input lag so far which has been an issue since FH3.*LOD issues. The terrible draw distance makes the terrain and foliage, which are already bad looking worse as 70% of the screen and view look pixelated and low res including the skies, like a game from 2010s. Black horizontal lines bars due to SSAO, broken textures, low fps crowd, pixelated smoke and dust etc.*Weather effects are recycled and not even improved upon and imo mostly worse. The only new thing is the dust storm which is basically the blizzard effect in brown. No more than bare minimum effort was put into water and rain effects, weather effects on the environment aren't great either. You have look in the menu to find which season it is.*For a game centred around fun, festivals and party, the UI is as basic as a formal ppt done in the last minute. *Festival locations are meh. Even Australia festivals were better to look at, from near and far.*Character customisation is the same as before with just different hairstyles to chose on the very specific stereotyped 3D scanned faces that look like nobody. The player talks now so that's new.*Vanity items are just handful, the emotes and most things are recycled from the last games.*Woke signalling nonsense, pronouns, prosthetic and face masks for whatever reason and that too in a racing game. They could've easily done a balaclava or bandanna instead but NO! they've just got to insert their political bs at every given chance because 2021.*The handling and physics is almost identical, Unless you're deep into tuning, you wont notice the difference.*The new engine sounds are there but I assume most people like myself would just turn down sfxs to listen to their playlist.*I don't mind multiple Horizon releases in a gen, we get more locations to drive in and that's great, but this game is downgraded in more things than it improves upon. Now I know why they would talk about nonsense like graffiti for hours all the time because they had nothing else new to show. FH4 was an actual generational upgrade from FH3 and people still liked FH3 better and still do, so remember that, most of these "improvements" are subject to preference.

author: Zeykron
review: If you like driving in GTA but want more cars and better driving mechanics, this game is a must have

author: Endosan
review: - Checkpoints are still the worst: NFS Heat did it better- Meta cars still dominates: lack of balance- Horrible ghosting system- Abusive wall penalties (inconsistent and too harsh)- Rammers do not get rightfully punished, unless reported with video evidence- Randomised qualify positions at start (likely prioritise fast connection)- Bone shaker still broken- Mexico map is forgettable, poor conditioned roads and bushy (quantity over quality)- Story mode is forgettable and boring. Also, no co-op with convoys and random players- Terrible light exposure where the map is too dark when it is afternoon- Lack of features compare to FH4- Wheelspin is now awful and grindy- You cannot skip dialogue in Super 7 - A stupid tree in the middle of ek balam CC circuit- Did I mentioned that Bone shaker is broken?- Drivatars are unfair and make you question life- You cannot do custom Horizon Opens: You are forced to race in Classes and race types randomly- Steering is still locked at 90 degrees. Where is the full 900 degrees?- Some livery artist got banned for making sfw anime liveries.- Playground games event is the same as FH4: a complete mess of a game mode- The Eliminator feels like a copy n paste, but different cars, horrible map and horrible stutter each time you do head to head. For some reason, final showdown does not have that horrible stutter issue. Also the game takes forever to reset your car, should it get stuck.- Playground game devs had years learning from their mistakes from Forza Horizon 4, but does not seem to care and poorly executed 5. Meanwhile Turn 10 are flawless with their support tickets.- Power builds are being meta- As of playing the game, it feels very unoptimized; constant stutters whenever you access the menu- Ui is too simple and not well designed compare to Forza Horizon 4. It's as if a 12 year old who has no experience in graphics design made it.- You cannot gift cars to specific players. Minor issue though- Leaderboards are still broken and filled with hackers filling up the top - Random convoy race is non-existent. The convoy in Forza Horizon 4 was fine, while 5's is too overcomplicate and inconvenient. In 4 you just go to an event, select co op or pvp and randoms could join in. 5 does not have that, because you have to create a convoy, state whether it is a road, dirt, street, etc. and wait for a player to join in before you select an event and start a race. Sounds complicated? Because it is!- Influences > Accolades  - The music in Forza Horizon 5 are mostly miss. Nothing is memorable and hospital music is bare bones. The previous Horizon games did it better- Ray tracing is only available in ForzaVistaI am aware that the devs are working hard to improve the game, but have they learn from FH4? The bone shaker being broken proved otherwise. In conclusion, I rather pay scalper price for a PS5 + Elgato capture card and Gran Turismo 7 than to play this repeated mess of a game.

author: KenGT1
review: As a player who played both Forza Horizon 3 and 4, This game is quite decent with new and returning features from both games. However, Most of the content in the current game is recycled such as some cars which are in FH4 are placed in Festival Playlist in FH5 as new content. Those cars should be at launch if there are no licensing issues unlike the case of Alfa Romeo, Fiat and Lancia that is the actual licensing issue. Also some features like Midnight Battles should reward the cars that are new to Forza instead of the cars that already exist in the first place. Bugs and glitches havenâ€™t been fixed properly even hotfixes in each updateDespite the recycled contents, The updates that FH4 doesnâ€™t make into it is the new customization such as new rims, new bodykits from other manufacturers besides Rocket Bunny and Liberty Walk. The bodykit of Hyundai Veloster surprises me unexpectedly and it becomes one of my favourite bodykits. Eventlab creates new areas or custom maps for drifting, photography and more. This new feature in FH5 helps the community create new things.The main map of FH5 is mixed between FH3 and FH4, FH3 brings diversity in each area of the map and returns multiple festival sites and the airport meanwhile FH4 brings historic city into it but the issue of FH5â€™s map doesnâ€™t have urban area like in FH3 map. So the map in FH5 is basically FH4â€™s map with many biomes. In terms of car list, Car Pass DLC is worth it for discounted price. Some cars are pretty good with proper customiztion but some new gen cars such as Audi should be free in Festival Playlist. New cars at the post launch don't have as much as I expected. Online mode is quite soulless unlike FH4 where most people are active in Forzathon events that make the event look like the car meet. Online racing and custom event is not different much as FH4Forza Horizon 5 is a sandbox-ish game where you can choose and buy one of your favourite cars to curise or race. Freedom and customizability are the key. So the overall score for this game is 7/10.

author: Polekatt
review: Highly recommend this game if you like racing games.   This is the game I wanted from the Crew games, NFS, and any other open world racer.   The game runs fine on my mid/low end computer, the puzzles are hard but not too hard to do, tons of cars, tons of stories and quests, things for everyone, but mainly its just plain fun.  And having fun is what matters most.

author: tyrannosaurus_fax_machine

This game is complete garbage if you have to start on a Hot Wheels Track, then transfer to Mexico, then realize that the game will never load the Mexico map, then force quit the f**king game, then restart the game, then end up in the Hot Wheels Map again, then transfer to Mexico so you can do the races you actually want... This is insanity please make it stop

author: Cheesus
review: This is everything Forza Horizon is about but better. Car sounds and the driving experience are amazing. The layout of Mexico is super rich and fun to drive around and the game runs great also.My only complaints are regarding the music selection and the hackers that are constantly dominating leaderboards with obvious cheated records on tracks.

author: nether
review: Singleplayer part and technical part of the game is great, even though I've experienced some crashes before resetting memory overclock, but the game runs smooth afterwards. Must be noted that game requires a lot of RAM either way it's gonna crash a lot (I've experienced the same issue with FH3/FH4 before installing additional 16 GBs of RAM to previous 16GBs)Even though this game is a "Forza Horizon 4 reskin", as everybody calls it, but it's still good. Devs can and will add feature with future updates like in FH4, of course this game has everything FH4 had, but it's now better and bigger and has a lot of time to become even better. The map is huge, elevation changes are insane comparing to previous games, different bioms and districts look great. Huge amount of different events, the biggest final races Horizon have had so far. Car collection is not that rich as it was in FH4, but it will be even bigger after a couple of seasons for sure.Seasons are great, but I miss ranked adventures. Without them usual adventures are full of tryhards with meta cars, overall adventures are useless unless you're doing daily challenges for season complition.EventLab should be mentioned too, - the tools that were given by devs are insane. Many players already have created stunning events with their own layout and rules and many yet to come.This game can be kind of boring, because it lacks good progression, but it's definitely good for chill racing or cruise alongside the coast. This game is the best arcade race you can find right now and probably in the next 5 years.Old detailed review under the spoiler:

author: Felidae
review: It's FH4 in Mexico, but that's fine, that's what I was expecting. But moreso, other than being FH4 in Mexico, it's FH4 but broken. If you're thinking of playing this game with friends, wait awhile. Networking issues plague the game with randomly disappearing cars, even worse if they're in your party. The devs have also setup social media for you to follow, some of which have been taken down or are vacant. The only news source for the games upcoming patches is a Q&A detailing bugs they dont intend to fix. Other than that, their latest priority was patching a jeep you could exploit for wheelspins, while simultaneously CREATING MORE bugs in the game. Wait until the game is finished, otherwise, wait until it is on sale, or just get FH4.

author: Hingle McCringleberry
review: I've always told my friends, even if Forza Horizon 5 was the worst game of the series. It would be well worth the money for the most expensive edition. Boy was I wrong... Between the accolades, seasonal events and other things that just don't register. The lack-luster game design, empty feeling map, no sense of progression. I honestly am very disappointed. The car selection is very good for release, but still some puzzling omissions. I've always been the biggest fan of the horizon series. I don't typically enjoy arcade racers, but Forza USUALLY hits that sweet spot. I dont know why they got rid of daily drivatars rewards... and where are the businesses? It just feels so grindy and pointless. You unlock all the races not through completing them, but special events? Where is the sense of progression? I could go on and on, this season has felt the most grindy so far. no variety at all. Buy this B series car and do a race, then buy this B series car and do a race. why not do races B through S1 and swap across race disciplines. I feel like they could have used so much more of the map as well. The beaches are empty and useless, near the west area, a whole off-roading area exists with no roads or anything. In summary, I don't expect I'll play this game much longer. If you want a great arcade racer, go buy FH4 on sale.

author: GravyLegs
review: Honestly, the more I play this game, the more I dislike it. Forza has lost the soul it once had, and now feels manufactured. Horizon 5 is an example of how the "Horizon" name in the Forza franchise is quickly becoming the open world racing equivalent to Fifa. This game has a lot of effort put into it, but zero heart and soul.

author: Eralsk
review: Although one of the best racing games in the market, Forza Horizon 5 on Steam lacks the bug-free gameplay most Xbox users experience. There are various graphical and gameplay glitches that make the game extremely less immersive. - Anti-Aliasing sometimes will devolve into an early 2000's pixel platformer.- Black polygons will show up from time to time on the surface of dirt areas.- In online mode, the car will suddenly stop after being disconnected from the server, resulting in the loss of a skill chain.- Landing in some areas of towns in the game from either Danger Zones or ramps will result in being trapped by unbreakable walls, buildings, or other objects.- In online mode, some player's cars will freeze mid-air after being launched from Danger Zones.- SSAO will sometimes lower in resolution mid-game, showing bars across the screen from the Horizon, making it harder to see distant objects when driving. (Ironic, really.)- LOD will sometimes turn into the 1st generation Source engine.- Crashes.- Long load times, even with a NVMe SSD.- Level-ups will sometimes not register, resulting in the game showing you as a level higher than you actually are, even when the rewards have been given.On a good note, the northern Mexico map is vast with great detail and realism, although a lack of potholes from my few times visiting Mexico myself. The selection of vehicles in the game is also a great improvement from FH4, and the details are extremely photorealistic. In addition, the gameplay and races are highly varied, and the substantial amount of online interactivity makes this game one of the best online racing games on PC.Though these bugs can be ignored from time to time, I have ran into issues involving a multitude of crashes due to lack of memory optimizations. Consequently, I have lost numerous amount of hours of progress on extensive wraps and decal group creations. I cannot recommend the current state of Horizon 5's PC port as of right now, and with later fixes I'll be enthusiastically inclined to change this review.

author: Colubrinus
review: While there is a lot to do, just about every mechanic in Forza Horizon 5 feels disappointingly surface level. AI drivatars are a joke, season challenges are often impossible due to a lack of quality control, a lot of non-seasonal challenges and achievements are bugged, the devs are banning people for making (or using) skins with copy-written materials on them. It's just a bad game. It feels like a slapped-together asset flip of previous Forza games pilled high with pointless, gimmicky new mechanics that might as well not be there since they didn't improve the base gameplay at all. In fact, driving, in general, feels worse. Handling is better granted, but the dreadful AI together with the terrible matchmaking ruin it. Unless you love driving around a mostly empty feeling sandbox world, or tuning cars, please don't buy this. It might be better with friends, but so is getting punched in the face.

author: LAGRIE
review: Forza Horizon 5------------------------------A solid racing games with tons of cars to collect, races to win and more.From customisation to world design. You have to hand it to microsoft for the visuals and gameplay.The only con i do have is the issues that the engine can have, connected to Nvidea overlay and raytracing.This is a solid package, a solid game and is great to play with friends.If you love forza, then get this, no questions asked.Enjoy the game !

author: M4F10S0
review: You as a superstar of Horizon festival in the UK is sent to Mexico to help build a new festival. The opening scene is awesome. You jump out of the plane in a car and your adventure can start. There will be a lot of work but it will be fun and you won't turn off the game.The game offers so many activities to do. You will be building not just one place for the festival, neither two but 5. Yeah, 5! Each race type has its own festival place plus a place for PR stunts. To do it you will need to collect accolades. These are small challenges. Some are easy to complete but there are some challenging as well. Big map of Mexico offers many races but not too much. I must say devs made a good amount of races. There are 4 types of races. Road Racing, Wild a.k.a. Dirt Racing, Baja a.k.a Cross Country and Street Racing. Everyone will find his favourite. Thanks to the big map that contains different areas from desert through fields, jungle, city to a high mountain which is a volcano. Races don't feel the same as in Horizon 4. I very like new stories and expeditions. There is a lot of them and they add more story feeling to the game. The game feels more like a racing game with a storyline than just plain racing over and over. Also, moderators in radios are responding to activities that you do in Mexico. By the way, radio stations have a good selection of music.The visual of Mexico is stunning. When you will climb on top of Vulcano you will be looking at the whole map with opened mouth. Another great thing is car sounds. Finally, they are nice! Horizon 4 has some cars that sound really good but it was just a few cars. Horizon 5 is completely another dimension and Dodge Viper has proper sound too ;). You know what? Try to change the exhaust on your car. Boom! The car has a new sound. Cars are changing sound when you upgrade them. Isn't it awesome? Devs did a great job with car sounds.A very important thing in racing games is handling. Forza Horizon has the best car handling from the amount of all open-world racing games. You can adjust it to your preferences. Yes, you can't make a simulator from it but if you turn off all assistants you will need the skill to keep your car on road. You can feel the weight of a car. Cars don't feel like karts. I'm looking at you - Need for Speed. Ok, what about the cars list? Well, it's... nicely chosen. You can find there more than 500 hundred cars. Horizon 5 has a very good economic system that doesn't let you grind many hours until you can buy a car that you want. Trust me. You can really fast make some credits and buy what you want. Also, you will get many cars for free from wheel spins or by completing activities. The auction house is there too so you can buy some expensive cars cheaper here. Cars have two new features. The first is every car has launch control. Just shift reverse gear and then back to the first gear (or press downshift and upshift together) and hold break with gas. Release brake and the car will get perfect launch. The second is working convertibles. Well working yeah, some convertibles can put the roof down or up but also there are still many cars that cannot. Hopefully, devs will add this feature to all convertible cars. Also Mercedes AMG One has two driving modes. Would be nice if devs use driving modes on more cars.As with all games, this one has some negatives as well. The launch of the game was not the best. There are some memory leaks, bugs and connection problems but devs are working on fixes, and I hope many of them will be fixed in the next big update.

author: Gamma Lyrae
review: A pretty fun "Adventure" themed open world racing game. It does a few things quite well in order to crack through to me, someone dealing w/ ADHD. In my experience, most open ended / open world games occupy one of two extremes: Completely directionless play (Minecraft Creative mode) and "The ubisoft tower" of completing one simple objective and having hundreds of chores immediately unlocked on your map. This game sits somewhere in between those, though its exact position oscillates as you play, and can be influenced by what you're doing.You start the game doing something cool immediately, and get to sample a few different kinds of cars and styles of racing right out of the gate. The game doesn't shy away from showing you how large its map is, but it intelligently hides most of the content that's on offer. Unlocking more is based on choices you make as you pursue the threadbare, albeit competent story the game has. It has an almost MMO-oriented pacing in regard to how you pursue content and unlock more to do. Different styles of races and environments have their own "quest givers" and "quests" to complete, which will unlock races that offer progression towards the next narrative beat, and a handful of side races that you can do for fun or rewards. If you ever feel stuck on what to do, the game contains an AI companion of sorts that you can call upon any time to guide you to an objective, loosely based on the kind of progression you've asked it to guide you to.I've played 60 something hours, dabbling in all of the race varieties I've come across, including setting foot into each major DLC. Nowhere near a "done" state with the game. I do think it becomes a bit less ADHD-accessible when you approach the end game, as the game gradually cares less about hiding what's available. The content distribution and volume is likely to have something you'll really enjoy, and you can really focus down on 1-2 styles of play and still have a ton to do.The only drawback with that play style is the reward mechanisms the game has, when combined with how many cars and other kinds of rewards there are. You might find yourself satisfied with circuit and street based racing, but if you want to unlock certain cars, certain emotes, and complete the story, you're going to have to engage with cross-country and off-road races, too.Not a bad game to play solo or with friends. Competitive types will likely end up disappointed, there isn't a ranked mode and the Horizon Open consisting of random races with random players takes away some of the satisfaction. Time trials exist for every course (whether they're official in-game courses or community made), though a significant portion of the top spots on the leaderboard are occupied by cheaters. Those that trail behind them have completely mastered the art of breaking the tuning system outside of its semi-realistic responses to your adjustments, extracting more performance from cars than they otherwise could, and they drive those cars exceptionally well. If you choose to compete here, you'll probably need to feel satisfied with placing in the top 5% or top 1% of times, or only comparing yourself to your friends.At the end of the day, this game has a ton to do, but the quality of any one thing it does is diminished. Not as much as you think, since this is the 5th Horizon game, built upon the legacy of the motorsports series that came before it, but other titles that specialize in one or two areas are going to be more satisfying to players seeking specific kinds of experiences (arcade/"fun" oriented physics, simulation-based physics, competitive racing in multiple formats, more concise track lists for the community to compete on and benchmark their performance with, etc.). Worth mentioning that there's an absurd amount of accessibility options to accommodate most disabilities and a dial your own difficulty system that will allow for just about everyone to play regardless of ability.

author: Hardy
review: I started my Horizon adventure just early 2021 when FH4 came to Steam. Instantly loved it, by October I had all the achievements and cars excluding 4 pre-order machines. Understandably I awaited FH5 since it was announced during E3. After 30 hours I can say the new instalment exceeded my expectations.From the moment menu kicks in with its captivating music evoking Mexico vibe so much, till the  Goliath race across the map, thereâ€™s so many aspects neatly executed here. Itâ€™s a step-up from the already good FH4 in almost every department.Graphics, lighting, map design (especially its huge verticality which I havenâ€™t seen in any other racing title to date). Audio, highlight of which being the sandstorm both looking and sounding insane. Everything is . 1.5x the map size of FH4. Longer drift zones. Online Forzathon events more fun to participate in. Online racing revamped in an immersive way (you drive to another destination with the same people you just raced with).Horizon Stories now having different episodes scattered throughout the world. Trailblazers, treasure hunts and  challenges incorporated from FH4â€™s DLC. Weekly festival playlist with new event types and twists (car brand/class restrictions for PR stunts â€“ Iâ€™m looking at you). Mexico rendition is so sunny and vibrant compared to gloomy Britain, with every part of the narrative telling its interesting culture.Driving model has also been improved upon. It needs a bit of time to get used to. Cars have more weight to them so understanding (and utilizing) weight transfer rules while cornering is more important. There are assist and difficulty settings to help you with the learning curve.FH5 runs great on my old i7-6700 and GTX 1060 GB. 60fps, bit less in intensive races (1920x1200 display, 'high' graphics preset which the game recommended itself). This was a nice surprise as before the launch I was sure Iâ€™d need to sell my kidney to buy RTX 3060.Online connectivity hiccups during early access weekend for Premium edition owners spoiled the fun, unfortunately. Seriously counting on some in-game compensation from Microsoftâ€¦To people saying itâ€™s just another FH4, let me explain. The series has always had two words in its name, every time both of them being  and . Itâ€™s just the following number that kept changing, and boyâ€¦ I wish every other numbered series improved at least as much from the previous iteration, simultaneously preserving its best features as successfully as FH5 does. 9/10

author: jettacar
review: Note: This review was written before the first patch. It will discuss issues that may not be present in the game anymore. I urge you to actually read the review before making an uneducated comment, because I actually don't hate this game. I genuinely love it, and will continue playing it. I'm simply giving an honest, unbiased review on some of the issues - as a long-time, avid player of all Forza titles.Forza Horizon 5 is the (buggy, dysfunctional) car game for non-car people.I really enjoyed this game. This is the most fun I've had in a Forza title in a very long time, and it's definitely miles above Horizon 4. However, I can not in good faith recommend a game that is clearly unfinished. This game REEKS of "rushed for a holiday release". There's so much wrong with this game, but they neglect to remedy most of it. There's a constant memory leak issue that reveals itself, usually around an hour of playtime, requiring a restart. I physically can not run the game on "Extreme" settings, even though my computer physically could. After ~5 minutes of driving around on max settings, the textures will begin to corrupt and the framerate will tank.Attempting to play with friends is a frustrating, grueling task that will likely result in you giving up and closing the game. Never in my life have I seen a game with such an unstable online mode, WHILE TRYING TO PLAY WITH SOMEONE ON THE SAME WIRED CONNECTION AS ME!The AI is also extremely frustrating. I have no idea what they did between Horizon 3, 4, and now, but the blatant disregard for the game's physics performed by the AI can get infuriating very quickly. The rubberbanding is extremely exaggerated in online play, as drivatars in completely stock C or D-Class cars will just decide to make manoeuvres as if they were on rails. Doing any sort of off-road race is a no-go unless you're AWD/4WD. Why? Because the AI will AWD swap every single car, without fail, every time. This makes attempting to enjoy a RWD or FWD rally car a very hard task, as every race will now become exponentially harder.This game is chock-full of graphical glitches too. Floating rocks, botched collisions, incorrect shading, the works. The Can-Am Maverick's rear quarter panels are void-black most of the time. I have no idea what factor plays into this, but it's not a constant issue. The Mercedes X-Class lacks a modelled engine (which it had in Horizon 4), and the Ford Racing Puma's hood will not open properly. Only the sound deadening of the hood actually goes up when you open it, the rest of the hood stays shut.NOTE: This next paragraph is entirely opinion.A personal gripe of mine that doesn't necessarily affect gameplay has to be the lack of vehicle variety and progression. If you're the type that likes steady, somewhat linear progression, where the supercars feel far more rewarding in the end, this is not the game for you. There is an extremely glaring omission of just, ordinary, everyday cars. The potential for upgrading could be so much better if we were simply given the regular counterparts of the cars, leaving the insane custom builds of them as a conversion kit. I simply don't understand this, because Forza historically, up until the mid 2010's was always very good about vehicle variety. Where is the Mexican domestic vehicles? I counted one. The Renault 4L. That is the only vehicle that is discernible as the Mexican market version. I would HAPPILY drive a Ford Topaz, Chrysler Spirit, Peugeot 404, Chevy Caprice, Dodge Ramcharger, Opel Fiera, the list goes on. They really dropped the ball on including Mexican vehicles in "The Mexican Car Game". Beetle this, Beetle that. The Beetle has been in nearly every â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ title. It's not new. Would it have hurt to include some more obscure/ordinary Mexican vehicles? I would bet money that nobody at Playground Games has heard of VAM. Another thing! Why the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ is there licensed traffic in this game? Just include the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ cars! You guys literally have the models for all of them already, because they're just ported from older titles.Anyways, this concludes my rant. This game has so much potential, but it really drops the ball on functionality. I wish people wouldn't happily advocate for pushing developers to release an unfinished game with the "it can be patched later!" mindset. I'm very happy for the record-breaking launch on this game, but clearly something was done differently that breaks the multiplayer in this. I just wanna play the â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ game with some friends.UPDATES:-Online sort of works now. Still nearly impossible to do a convoy free mode road trip, due to players popping in and out all the time. But I've had 0 issues within races as of recently!-The texture corruption glitch that happens during a memory leak has been fixed, but the memory leaks themselves still happen.

author: Invador0007
review: This is the series at its best if you enjoy what Forza Horizon does. It's the type of game that will keep you amused for as long as you have to play it. It won't satiate the cravings of simulation experts, but it won't try. For everyone else, Forza Horizon 5 is the racing game to play.This is not a rival to Assetto Corsa. It's a game you can play again and over again and feel like you've accomplished something. Personally, I'm fully captivated, and I'm sure I'll be playing this game for a long time.Yeah there are some bug but not game breaking which will be ironed out soon I hope.

author: CapAllan
review: I was introduced to the Forza franchise through FH4 on game pass. I was about to buy it on Steam when FH5 was announced and I decided to hold off for this, and I'm glad I did. This is better in almost every way and there's so much to do and collect that it can even be a bit overwhelming at times (and that's a good thing)! I wasn't expecting a game that looks this good to run really well, but it does (apart from a few dips here and there). The game rewards you for your time and you'll always be unlocking something throughout your playtime. If you're looking for another game to grind and to try and unlock everything, I'd recommend getting some of the DLCs or the premium edition to help with that. Otherwise, I'd recommend getting the base game/playing this on Game Pass instead, all of which will still get you a remarkable experience!

author: Tom.
review: I finally got online mode to work after months of connection issues, although now I need to use a VPN. I can now say this is most addicting and fun race sim-cade game I have ever played. Huge map, a large selection of cars (and Ferraris lol) with tons of customization, incredible graphics and a great sound design. author: Fairyteller
review: (A review of Forza Horizon 5 coming up as soon as I finish drifting down the volcanoâ€¦)An open world racing game chock full of cars, races, drifts and sweet jumps, Forza Horizon 5 is a fun ride through Mexico that maintains the core fundamentals of what made Horizon 4 a lot of fun, while improving several aspects of the game. New and returning players alike are both guaranteed a lot of fun here. They are indeed, doing it better than any other open world racing game on the market!Yes. I usually start my reviews talking about the gameâ€™s story, but since Horizon 5 doesnâ€™t have a traditional story, Iâ€™ll discuss the gameplay in detail.At its core, Forza Horizon 5 is an  with a lean towards the arcade end of the â€œarcade-simâ€ slider. Youâ€™re dropped into , complete with  After youâ€™ve been dropped off in the hub, the game gives you a small number of races and stunts to complete so that you can earn points and unlock more races and story missions. Itâ€™s then up to you to decide what you want to do. Maybe youâ€™ll explore the whole map, discovering new locations and collectibles? Or maybe youâ€™ll spend hours drifting a Supra, testing how many millions of combos you can get? Or maybe youâ€™ll work your way up the volcano  and see how far you can launch the Corvette off a ramp? Letâ€™s talk about what Horizon 5 offers you in terms of racing.  You unlock every race type by progressing through the story mode and once unlocked, you can participate in any available race whenever you want. Youâ€™re also free to do any race with whichever vehicle you want and the AI will match your car type and performance class. Want to race down a volcano in classic muscle cars? You can. How about racing trucks through a rainforest? Go wild. With the exception of the weekly challenge races, the game never forces you to use a certain vehicle type for a race, adding immensely to its replay value. The gameâ€™s weather also changes every week, so a you might find yourself drifting in the middle of a sandstorm in the weather one week, followed by a race in a thunderstorm the next and then racing atop a frozen volcanic crater the week after that. One of the things that has had a substantial overhauling from Horizon 4 to 5 is the gameâ€™s progression system.  They range from the simple, like winning races or 3 starring a stunt, to challenging, like driving from one place to another in a certain car within a time limit or stringing together a specific skill chain. Once youâ€™ve collected a certain amount of points, the game gives you an unlock point so you can unlock a chapter of your adventure. Every chapter costs 1 point apiece, so youâ€™re free to unlock whichever chapter youâ€™d like. Some challenges even unlock emotes, chat lines and new cars, so youâ€™ll always wanna keep an eye out.I mentioned Horizon 5 being closer to an arcade racer than a sim racer earlier. Basically, before you start of any race, the game lets you choose from multiple available difficulty modes and driving assists, with harder difficulties and no assists rewarding you extra money. The game also has a pretty  allowing you upgrade a carâ€™s engines and transmission for more speed and acceleration, or tyres and drivetrain for better handling and so on. Thereâ€™s also a pretty  that lets you fine tune exactly how you want your car to feel. Itâ€™s not a lot compared to any serious sim, but itâ€™s still pretty extensive. Unfortunately, the game doesnâ€™t explain the tuning system in much detail, but for those who just want to get to the racing without having to learn about rebound stiffness and camber, you can always download player made tunes for any car and get straight to the action. Speaking of player made tunes, letâ€™s talk about some of the gameâ€™s online features. The game lets you  If your work gets used, you even make some money in game! Every race in game can be co-oped against the AI with a team of upto 6 people, and you can also play PvP. Horizon 5 also offers two game modes exclusive to PvP, the Playgrounds mode and the Eliminator. Playgrounds mode is a series of modes where you team up with others to take on the enemy in games of tag and soccer. Eliminator is Horizons take on the battle royale, pitting upto 50 players in a game of survival. There are also hourly events, the Horizon Arcades, where you have to complete a bunch of mini missions with other players in 10 minutes for points that you can redeem in the game store for rare cars or cosmetics. Want a certain car, but itâ€™s too expensive or rare? Thereâ€™s the auction house in game where you can bid on cars against other people! With so many online features and the weekly challenges, itâ€™s easy to see why Horizon has sometimes been called a racing mmo.Making an open world look and sound good is a huge part of the immersion. How does Horizon 5 stack up in this?Freaking phenomenally, thatâ€™s how. Each of the gameâ€™s biomes looks and sounds spectacular. A lot of detail has been put in the game and it shows. Even on medium and low graphics settings, you can go on top of a cliff in the canyons or the volcano and look around for miles in game. The world is full of little details, like small dogs and donkeys roaming about in fields and villages, who will always manage to avoid your car! Driving in the desert, through a sandstorm is as thrilling as youâ€™d expect, because you can see itâ€™s size looming over you as you approach it. The lakes and canals in game dry up in the hot season and then fill back up in the rain and storm season. All of this is exceptional attention to detail, and its brought to life with amazing graphics. The city of Guanajuato is also reproduced pretty well, with great recreations of its historic landmarks, streets and tunnels. A plus work all around in the graphics department.The game sounds just as great as it looks as well. The cars sound great, and when you change their engines or exhausts, that change is reflected in game as well. That is great attention to detail and a massive improvement on Horizon 4â€™s stock car sounds. The gameâ€™s soundtrack is good. Iâ€™ve already found a few new favorites, though you mileage might vary on this. Forza Horizon 5 is one of the greatest racing games Iâ€™ve played and certainly a top contender for best game of 2021. If youâ€™re a fan of any sort of racing game, youâ€™re gonna have a fun time playing this. Even at full price, this game is worth every penny.

But I am not jumping through hoops again to get this game working. A user shouldn't have to play through the support team and troubleshooting procedures to have some enjoyment. Especially if the user works for 8 hours a day for 5 days a week or longer. I am not spending hours fixing an issue that should have not existed. review: Despite my hours in the game, I've grown dissatisfied with this title more and more over its run. Once they announced the second expansion, I was even more dissatisfied. I bought the ultimate edition of this game which if I had known I wasn't going to get the special ford deluxe with the steam version of the game even though I bought the special edition controller which only worked for like 3 months. Content updates for the game were abysmal and lacked any replay value. This game is as stale as it gets and I can't believe after all the years I spent playing the forza games, this is what it's come down to. Forza motorsport looks like it's going the same route. Until they present a fully working title with less of the crappy content updates and more to actually do besides watch a bunch of 3 year olds v12 awd sawp every car in the game and claim skill for winning in the broken meta, I will not be recommending this game to anybody or buying another forza game and I'm sure many of us feel the same way.

I can even put the game at 4K and get 60-70FPS with Extreme Quality.Forza Horizon 5 is the pinnacle of arcade racing games:- Over 500 cars to collect- A massive Mexico map to explore- Plenty of different activities to do- A lot of difficult options- Magistral visuals- Really good customization about characters and carsAnd as usual in Forza Horizon, amazing OST.I played the 4th one like crazy and I'm glad that Forza Horizon 5 improves many things.To put it simply, Forza Horizon 5 is soo fun. A proper wholesome game!Can't recommend it enough !

author: BrianH1988
review: For the record: I bought the Ultimate Edition. I have all prior games with all prior expansions/DLC for Forza Horizon, and almost everything going all the way back to Forza 2 on that side. I am massive, massive Forza fan and it's likely someone playing one of these for the first time may not even be able to associate some of these as issues, what with the game industry just generally being as unacceptably bankrupt with product launch and post-game support as it has been lately. I want to make it abundantly clear before the rest of this kicks off: I believe they can fix or at least remedy most if not all of the problems with this game... given a few months' time and a lot of elbow grease, though there may potentially be some things they just cannot patch out as issues- namely the current iteration of the driveatar system, or complete lack thereof, and what they appear to have replaced 16 years of Turn 10's work with.Because I'm going to be so harsh on it after this, let me point out some serious positives to this game first. Amazing world design overall, up there if not outright matching that of Forza Horizon 3 while adding the wrinkles of seasons from Forza Horizon 4. Graphically masterpiece-tier. The raytracing reflections on the car running on my 1080 make the cars look closer to what they did in Forza 7- like cars rather than overglossy plastic. I couldn't bring myself to play with it off, even with the performance hiccups it might be bringing- it was too integral to the feel of the game. Fantastically executed. The world, too, feels like a living, breathing place. Sandstorms will kick up in the dry season (in weird places, mind, and sadly do not affect physics or handling that much). Most of the map transforms into a slick during the wet season, and the mists that swirl in the swamp can and will give way to random bouts of fog. This game, for all its faults, is still without question a technical triumph on what they've put together (don't conflate this with smooth performance, more on that later). I recommend going to see Digital Foundry's video on optimized settings for FH5. I was able to get it to run at 50-60 on a GTX 1080 with those, for what metric that may be worth (I also run a setup with four 1080P monitors and it was running on one of those, so take that with a slight grain of salt).This game has also now beaten the desire straight out of me to play it until they fix some of the more glaring issues. Between the patch on the 3rd of December, and what immediately seems like they've completely dropped the work Turn 10 has done on the driveatar system to have a unique selling point... They have instead replaced the built up AI behavior, and just made what you're racing against based on replays which I can only assume they intend to use machine learning on (which on all difficulties are sped up). It's intensely annoying to race against, and takes me out of the experience so often.Graphically the game is a marvel... but you're going to drop well below 60 regularly even on a GTX 1080 because they omitted some very essential optimization features, not least of which is the intensive and GPU consuming process of cloud generation. There are no options for that, it thinks my monitor runs at 59 hertz and does not give me an option to force 60 for proper VSync to function, and on top of that, as Digtal Foundry has noted in their optimized settings guide, the VSync option provided will give you a fairly decent-sized performance hit regardless of system, and you're better off just turning on VSync in your graphic's card's control panel. The result is a game that cannot run smoothly even above natural refresh rate and literally required the game ready drivers or better to not be a total performance mess (bizarre thing I'm not sure how many have run into: at one point I had 3-5 crashes an hour, I was never able to track down a reason, it just... stopped at one point during my last week with the game). Give it, at minimum, a few months, I'd argue. Right now it's not the refined experience you expect if you've played a prior entry (even from the relatively jank launches this side franchise has had compared to the main Forza's titles), and doesn't even have many of the options and features of the prior entry that were there at launch. Whether you can look past these issues or not... do your research a little, because unfortunately, a text review cannot exemplify most of the problems this game has very aptly, nor are you guaranteed to have anywhere near the same experience as I did. As always, your mileage will vary.And thus, the condition of this thing smarts, and it smarts hard. It smarts that higher difficulties literally play out like sped up replays that have been spliced together. It smarts that the AI gets a massive head start and rubber bands like there was no conception of time in the game. It smarts that the AI completely ignores the laws of physics you must obey in accordance to these replays, breaking my immersion in the only way I have to engage with it much while I have no patience for the netcode. It smarts that there's so much good... hindered by so many issues. To the devs: Please fix, I'll wait. When you're charging $100 for the full product ahead of time, your fans deserve better than what you have delivered, and we have come to expect far better than what you have delivered on PC already from the past two games. Do us a solid and bring back the driveatar system, if it's even possible. It was a far better solution than this... thing... you've hackneyed together to replace it.

author: JDumbz
review: Forza Horizon is back and now in Mexico!For quite some time I have been itching for a new racing game to get into. Fortunately, Forza is back for some time. I will say straight to the point if you like Forza Horizon 4, you will certainly enjoy 5. During my almost ten hours on early access, the game was engaging, more than most racing games that were released in the past few years. - As always, Forza has a neat selection of cars to pick from. At launch, we have the choice to pick over 500 Cars!- Bigger map, bigger exploration! I always admire Mexico, the culture, the atmosphere, I'm biased to say this is my favorite location in the Forza Series aside from Australia.- New Sounds, handling improvements, the handling model too feels different but in a good way.- Graphical Improvements, weather effects, smoke effects.- A new fair addition to customizations, however, still not meeting NFS quality. - Connection Issues. Understanding the game is just released with a day zero patch, this will be addressed soon.- Lack of story (as expected) but brace for the cringe dialogue.- Lack of progression. I do like rewarding progression more, so everything is handed to you like previous titles.- Texture issues, map disappearing. However, this has been noticed and will be addressed.- Crashes, mostly GPU issue overheating. If you have a RX 5700XT I do have a workaround that may be a ((fix)). Please read below:Playground games cause a lot of stress for this card, for the people who have Black screens or Shutdowns in minutes of playing. I encourage you to look for Fan Curve Speeds and change it to 50% before playing the game. I went from 87C+ down to 73C and was able to play for hours straight with no problem. In my theory, the card does not cool down fast enough with factory settings as the game puts your card on 100% load instantly. If this does work for you, let me know, please. I mentioned this to a few people to try and has fixed their problems. these are the settings I tried and have fixed my Shutdown problems while playing a few minutes.Overall if you're looking for a decent Arcade-Sim, Forza Horizon is a nice pick. Though, I would also encourage you to try the game out on Gamepass if you're unsure as a demo. You do get a discount too as well for buying premium with it.

author: Walkman
review: This game is the copy paste from FH4 with a little bit better graphics but with ton of bugs which makes this game unplayable. There are new missions that were marketed as coop-missions but you can`t play them with friends. There is no new content in the game compared to FH4. Everything is basically the same with some improvements. Online has the same issues as FH4 had. You have to wait 10+ minutes to join the race.I`ve bought premium edition and the bonuses for VIP doesn`t work (or at least you can`t see it).On top of that there are a lot of bugs:- Lot`s of crashes- Constant disconnects from online- Unable to join friend's lobbies- Friends/Players vanishing in front of you- Sudden stops during race as if there is a wall in frony of youâ€¢ Buggy textures (yesterday all of the buidings for me kept vanishing when i was near them)I like it because i enjoyed FH4 (also new car sounds are incredible) but i expected a lot more for the 100 USD edition gameDon`t buy it right now. Wait until it`s in playable state.If the devs fix it in the future for FREE i will reconsider my reviewUpdate:It has been almost a month since the release and nothing has changed.The game has the same issues and there is no communication when the devs will fix the game.On top of the previous bugs now you can`t even do weekly challenges if you have completed expedition and story mode before.11.03.2023 nothing really changed. they add 4 cars every patch. some of them not even new but copy pasted from FH4. the dissapointing part this game is boring. i only play it because there is no casual open world racing game right now on the market
