author: the man who drew the world
review: Currently playing with:CPU: Ryzen 3800XGPU: XFX RX 580 8GBRAM: 16 GBActually pretty fun but has some issues. This is my first intro besides a little bit of gameplay from Horizon 3, and my review will be limited to the premium edition as that's what I got and other players who only have the base game may have a different experience. That being said, my other friends don't have the premium and don't feel like they are missing out on much so do with that what you will, obviously the big bonus of premium is the future content/expansions being bundled and discounted rather than having to purchase them separately.Pros:Great variety and customizationGreat graphics and optimizationFun to play online with friends and take part in eventsLots of things to doThe way they are doing seasons seems interesting, but also wish that they could be longer than 3-4 days each for the small ones.The rewind feature works incredibly well, especially online. I'm honestly amazed at how they were able to implement it so seamlessly, and it adds a lot to the game and helps tone down frustration if you are trying to complete specific objectives in free roam as well. That being said, the only time I've ever had the game crash (2 at this time) have both been related to me rewinding and the game freezes and crashes shortly afterward. Haven't been able to notice anything in particular that might have set it off.Meh:Lots of small details in the game when you are playing, but also weirdly enough a lack of them, hopefully some features will get implemented later like skipping cutscenes, and other UI decisions that will probably be suggested by the Horizon community.I'm sure there's more stuff but I'll probably add stuff in as I play more.Cons:Story is forced and it's literally torture having to watch unskippable cutscenes with terrible acting and lines. Wish we could skip all the animations that are in the game like the barn finds as well.Other story events are annoying where you are racing some AI like in the showcase events where they look like they are rubberbanding all over the place. The first showcase event with the motorcycles has it bad, and the bikes literally look like they are floating on the ground while they are driving, there's no actual substance to their movements if that makes any sense.Online definitely has issues, constant DC's, being forced to go into free roam from whatever menu you are in just to reconnect, players in your convoy disappearing in front of you or on the map, etc. Also weirdly enough your car stopping anytime you get DC's, which is super frustrating for those who get DC'd often. By that time a restart usually ends up resolving it though.Some parts of online, especially Arcade are frustrating mostly because of a lack of players, there isn't much incentive to play them, which makes it all the more harder if you are trying to do any seasonal or whatever objective and there is literally no one at each point. Maybe a queuing feature could mitigate that? Alternatively just play with friends but they aren't always available.The XBOX live integration leaves something to be desired, sometimes it just won't connect to online even though in game I am online and can play with friends. It's easiest to just join a friend by sending them an invite through in game instead of the XBOX overlay, or them specifically joining you outright.All in all though I'd say the game has been worth it so far, and I look forward to the improvements they'll make and whatever else will happen down the line.

author: NitroNinety
review: I remember just as this game released, I was watching a review from some big name site, and they gave the game a perfect 10. They pretty much said it was one of the best racing games ever. I owned FH4, got all the passes and DLCs and whatnot. So I paid 100â‚¬ for this one too, seeing as it was supposed to be a 10/10 game.So I bought the thing and quickly realized someone was lying to me. What was released was essentially a half-product, something that needed months of fixes and updates. And now, even after these months have passed, trees and leaves are still popping up when you drive closer and there's flickering in more detailed textures. And sadly this isn't on lower-end settings, I own a decent setup.How they still haven't been able to address this is beyond me, there are comments about this all over the net. There have been constant updates and the developers have acknowledged to having technical difficulties. So why a well-known review site have it a perfect 10 is beyond me. Sadly I've fallen for the hoax and shelled out a fair chunk of money for a game that isn't worth it even after several months of updates.FH4 was, and still is, a lot more enjoyable, so I can't fathom how they've managed to screw up the visuals so bad this time.  If they ever manage to fix the constant flickering and foliage popups, I'll get back to it, but for now, I've uninstalled it. Shame, if you ask me.

author: FEELs
review: After sinking in a reasonable amount of time I can comfortably say that forza horizon 5 expands on what forza horizon 4 brought to the table, at the same time spicing things up with a variety of new landscapes for new and returning players to the franchise to experience. Having said that it does suffer from minor bugs as of writing this review, but nothing game breaking. In summary it's a solid racing game that manages to blur the line between an arcade and sim racer, which hits the sweet spot while providing a proper triple A experience.Side note- yes, it does have anime waifu decals in case you were wondering, need I say more?

author: thepowerglove
review: 2/2/22 edit: I've put some more hours into the game and after recent changes and updates, I absolutely cannot recommend this game to new players. Many of the features such as accolades remain broken, online is still dodgy, and they have completely gutted many of the game reward amounts. Any new players will be hugely behind everyone who was able to get lots of money and good cars when the rewards were higher.Online works a bit better, but it's marred by bad matchmaking, cheaters, horrid lobby system, no ranked racing, and no way to enter into certain classes or race styles. Creative features do not allow you to save and edit maps (they've been promising this feature for a while, but instead prioritized reducing player rewards.)I will make one amendment to my previous review, turning off many of the driver controls, stability, etc makes drifting feel a lot better.==============Original review:The game itself is pretty good as a single-player experience but I can't recommend it for the multiplayer aspect which is being touted as the major feature. Most online activities are busted, Arcade challenges are bugged and when they do work you're lucky to get 2 or 3 players, limited communication options, player cars rarely populate into the world making it feel like a ghost town, and there are constant connection issues, not counting frequent crashes and other horrible bugs.I got the premium edition and so far it has absolutely not been worth it. The VIP benefits often "forget" to register correctly, the welcome pack cars are quickly outclassed by a few wheel spin wins or a decent upgrade.  I do plan on playing further to see if they can patch this game closer to what was advertised, and will revisit my review accordingly, but so far it's been a let down.Also of note:-Drifting is fun but drift scoring is wack. Feels like you get twice as many points drifting at 50MPH at 10 degrees than 40MPH going sideways.-Playing for one weekend I've already discovered 100% of the roads on the map, own a quarter of all cars and all but one house, did all barn finds, and found 90% of various other collectibles. The map is dense, but kind of small, I think I had a lot of time to explore because online doesn't work well...

author: S7
review: This is a review for the Hot Wheels DLC, which I recently finished.I was so excited to experience a Hot Wheels DLC after missing out on FH3, but this DLC is just not good.I've seen a lot of people complain that the DLC is bad because it's just full throttle all the time, but I actually think that's one of its strengths. Hot Wheels is meant to be all about super high speeds and gravity defying layouts. The real problem is that Hot Wheels Park has absolutely terrible flow. It seems like absolutely zero thought was put into the layout of the map. Honestly, did the devs even playtest this DLC? Off the top of my head, here are some examples of track sections with bad design:> Sideways track (non-magnetic) that is too banked, so gravity pulls you towards the guard rail and you lose all your speed> Braking zones over a crest where there is low grip, so you crash into the guard rail and lose even more speed than is necessary> Uphill / almost vertical acceleration zones, where you take ages to build speed while the AI powers on and easily overtakes you> The half-pipe, which has absolutely no grip when you are not on the racing line, making it extremely boring to drive through> Extremely inconsistent physics on magnetic track, resulting in unpredictable car handling and acceleration> Sharp turns or heavy braking zones placed right after blind sections of track (like a loop) which are impossible to foresee so you just slam into the barrier (but the AI is programmed to take it perfectly)> The fact that you can't complete loops in most low cars because the force pushing you into the track is so great that the bottom of your car literally clips through the floor, losing you speedAnother problem with the DLC is the Hot Wheels Academy which is supposed to be the main attraction. Who on earth thought it would be a good idea to lock you out of using FAST CARS in HOT WHEELS and force you to use crappy slow cars that can barely go up a ramp? Not only does this make progression annoying, but it also just breaks the game. Even after becoming a Hot Wheels legend and unlocking X-class cars, certain maxed out cars (e.g. FE Sesto, BTTB) are UNUSABLE in Hot Wheels Park because their hidden PI rating is too high and the game thinks your Academy Rating is too low so it forces you to change car...Another big letdown with this DLC is the track builder. The opening race is - sadly - the best part of the DLC, because it takes you around the whole map and they even spend all this time explaining all the cool new track pieces (which is unfortunately plagued with cringe Forza dialogue). For some reason, however, they don't let you use ANY of these in Eventlab??? All you can do is place orange track, crossroads, and boosters... No Air Track, no Ice Track, no Water Flume, no Magnet Track, no Halfpipe. Oh yeah on the topic of massive disappointments, I should also mention that the Hot Wheels Goliath is garbage. It's meant to be the flagship race of the DLC but instead of taking you through the cool parts of the map it's just a mindless cruise around the perimeter with a few loops thrown in here and there. The weekly A-class event around the Ice Cauldron was more fun than the Goliath, which is saying a lot considering how often these weekly events are mind-numbingly boring.To top it all off, the racing is awful. The pre-made races are extremely short and like usual in Forza, you start right at the back. This makes it impossible to win at higher AI difficulties because there's isn't enough time to overtake everyone unless you ram into them early on. In addition to this, the track is narrow and the guardrail on both sides prevents you from dipping your wheels into the dirt to try and get past as is possible in the base game. Add to this the myriad of track layout issues I mentioned earlier and you get a recipe for disaster.Epic fail.

author: InVader
review: Overall? Absolutely recommend it, but maybe not for full price (idc how delusional western companies get with their prices, I'll never pay more than 50 euros). From what I've heard Premium Pass isn't worth buying either, because the content updates are insignificant, so beware. Just get the Hot Wheels stuff if you enjoy the game and want more.- , on par with what you had in something like DiRT 2/DiRT Rally, but with much better tarmac/grip physics. A bit simcade-ish.- Totally . I only have anti-break-lock assist enabled, but for some RWD muscle cars I also enable traction control. No other assists needed.- . You can play this game and practically enjoy a vacation to Mexico through it. You get to see 1:1 replicas of real-life landmarks (e.g. Aztec/Mayan pyramids).-  Yes, some are duplicates in different configurations (e.g. a regular 240SX and a Formula Drift 240SX), but it's still hilarious to me that people complaining about the car roster, when they probably haven't used a 10th of what's in the game. Admittedly, having some eastern-European car brands like Å koda and Lada would be nice though.- very . This is the 2nd prettiest RTX game I own (after Amid Evil). My AMD 5800X + NVidia RTX2070 run it at solid 75 fps on ultra/extreme settings with ray-tracing on.- The  - much stronger than in your average NFS game. Combine that with the spectacular car physics and you get a game where you actually have to know how to drive really well. On hardest difficulty you might even have to strategize in order to win, e.g. in one of my early races I started last and the 1st guy always built up a big lead and the race ended by the time I would've reached him. The trick was to not overtake the 2nd guy early, because he was able to stay in drafting distance of the 1st guy, so I basically had to do a slipstream train with him and bumper-boost him, until we eventually both overtook the 1st guy at the same time.- The ! It knows how to defend the inside line leading to corner and seems to have personalities: some are cheeky and will use you as a wall in corners, while others respect your space.- The  - this goes as far as everyone taking rally cars with official liveries if you take one like that, or e.g. If you upgraded some old Toyota Celica to 800bhp, the AI will also take old cars that got tuned up to beasts.- Nice , if you're willing to take different cars to races - take a buggy, trophy truck or SUV and you can get something like a DiRT 2 Raid or Landrush race, because the AI will match the car class. Also, it's not just circuit races. There's A->B rally/trailblazer/road race type races, as well as stunts drifting, gymkhana, rallycross, Baja off-road stuff... There's also underground street racing, which is a road/circuit racing but with traffic enabled. It is possible to take any car to any race type, but you're obviously going to have a bad time, if you take a RWD 1600 bhp Koenigsegg with racing slicks to an off-road race (then again, so will the AI, because they match your car class).-  is extensive. You can also set it up the aforementioned Koenigsegg with rally suspension and tires and change the drivetrain to AWD to fit it for off-road racing. Customization in terms of custom body parts however is not as extensive as in your usual NFS game, especially in the case of hypercars. Most of the upgrades are functional, affecting strictly only the car's power and behaviour.- . Other games (like NFS or DiRT) have you start with a slow car, which you can upgrade&tune to be better towards the end of the game, while also progressively unlocking better cars until you get a Lambo towards the end of the game. Forza Horizon 5 doesn't have that. You unlock stuff in the most random order. In fact, unlocking new stuff is partially tied to "wheelspins" (read: slotmachine), where you get a random cash reward or unlock a new cosmetic, a new car, whatever. Afaik, there's no way to buy additional rolls on the wheelspin for real money. You can also just buy new cars for in-game cash in any order you want. In just 2 hours I accumulated $1 million and the cars have their real-life prices reflected in-game, so I can buy almost any supercar with that money right off the bat. I started with a 2022 Supra, then rolled an old Celicia and a 2014 Porsche Spyder on the slotmachine. As you can probably tell, all 3 of these are in vastly different classes in terms of speed. Then I upgraded the Celica to the Spyder's level for less than 100k. So like I said, there's no order to unlocking anything.- . Also somewhat boring. I'm European, so seeing ancient Mayan pyramids is interesting for me, but only for the first time and some random latino guy going  kinda ruins the experience. Just speak Spanish or just English, make up your mind smh. While these are "main" missions, there's a not lot of them, and the races are very much fun. , do whatever you want, the game isn't really meant to be finished 100%.- Speaking of sandbox, after building some festivals, the game will take a crap on your world map and fill it to the brim with markers - basically you get the  but for a racing game.- The  have these silly side-objectives, where you need to run over some boxes in some area, take some screenshots in photo mode etc.. Some of them can be a bit annoying to get, but you want the accolade rewards from them for unlocking new stuff.-  is exactly what you expect it to be: just a bunch of . I was doing a weekly event in multiplayer where a team of players was racing a team of hardest AI. The more AI we overtook the more points we got. I got a good exit out of the final corner, which set me up to overtake the my teammate just before the finish line, but he pushed me into a wall instead. It wasn't even a case of getting extra points for 1st place because we were 3rd/4th. We only get points for overtaking AI, so he did it for no reason other than having a fragile little ego. There's no punishing them for this, you can't report unsportsman-like behavior like in simracers.

author: Gordon Freeman
review: You'll be winning all the time with no effort so you want increase the difficulty by one. Well, prepare to cry because you have just enabled rubber banding except it works backwards. Most likely there will be a cluster of cars far behind you and one to three cars way ahead of you. If you're gonna lower the difficulty again, you'll have the same cluster behind you but it grows bigger the lower the difficulty. This is really frustrating but luckily the only thing in the game that annoys me.Otherwise the game is great!

author: MikeOhxmul
review: - THIS IS AN ARTICLE FOR PEOPLE WHO'S LOOKING TO BUY THIS GAME OR NEW TO IT -Hello, I am a forza horizon player with almost 250 hours of playing, im writing this to help people understand the state of the game and if they should buy or wait. 1 - CARS ; The game has 650 Cars to meet, a lot of customization, and tons of fun tweaking em so there should be no issue with it unless we go to the graphical side its quite interesting, Sometimes the car board glitches to the point its like turning the lights on and off ( NOT GAME BREAKING AND IT DOESN'T HAPPEN OFTEN, ITS A RARE ONE )2 - THE MAP :The game is set in mexico OBVIOUSLY great atmosphere and detailed so you won't get board looking at the great side of it the visuals the terrain and the sky, keep in mind the game is mostly at day the night is way shorter than the day. 3 - ONLINE :You can choose between ONLINE ( HORIZON LIFE ) or OFFLINE ( SOLO ) the game has a good online system you will spawn in a lobby full of people around the map witch you can interact with them, and invite or get invited to join a party ( CONVOY ) Its CROSS PLATFORM MULTIPLAYER so you can play with your Xbox friends as well and you won't get disconnected constantly IT HAS BEEN FIXED  / THE ONLINE RACING MODE ( HORIZON OPEN ) HAS GOOD MODES IN IT   / BATTLE ROYAL ( ELIMINATOR )   / RACING PVP PVE ( DRIFTING - ROAD RACING - CROSS COUNTRY - STREET RACING - RALLY - PLAY GROUND )4 - STORY :Nothing Much in it Just typical expeditions little short but not too shabby ( THEY ADD SOME STORY CONTENT ONCE A WHILE )5 - LACK OF DLC'S ( EXPANSION 1 / 2 )The game is around 7 month old ( THE TIME OF THIS ARTICLE ) no expansions whatsoever so if your new you have plenty of time to play and finish the game collecting cars and stuff until the dlc come out but for people who's been around quite a while its little bit boring now BUT DLC EXPECTED TO RELEASE SOON MIGHT BE SERIES 10 SINCE WE HAVE AN XBOX SHOW CASE IN THE NEXT MONTH ( June 12, 2022 ) so probably we'll have some news 6 - GLITCHES AND GAME BREAKING STUFF :So the game had a rough start but slowly they are improving it with each update so i'd say its in a good state when it comes to glitches the only downside and a game breaking for me is the horizon festival COOP EVENT LAB for a lot of people including me EVENT LAB COOP WON'T JUST WORK you wait until it find a session then you keep on waiting and nothing happens goes back to the open world driving

author: nav
review: 11/10 cars (lots of cars, mods, upgrades, tunes by community, liveries by community, customization)11/10 physics (perfect blend of sim and arcade, can be competitive even with keyboard (me) dont need a wheel or a controller)11/10 map (big even without the dlcs which are not out yet, detailed,  lots of variations, fun), 11/10 graphics even on medium settings (me)9/10 tracks (lots of tracks and most of them are fun, i just wish there is more option of a real circuit like horizon mexico circuit in the game not just random roads in circles)8/10 online racing (why cant we pick the class and type of races???)6/10 offline racing (copy pasted AI from fh4 and the fh4 AI is just average but not bad)2/10 "story" (cringe af, souless, nothing i can even remember from it really, cringe voice acting, cringe characters, cringe storyline, but the way they present the map which forces us to explore the map is really nice but exploring with some fatass kid who is the son of Pablo Escobar telling me about how great he is at flying planes is not really a nice experience) 7/10 replayability for most people (the festival playlist that's new every month is fun and will keep people playing to collect the cars and online is fun but there is no rank/competitive online mode only rivals (which is pretty much time trials to be the fastest on the leaderboard which is not as fun as racing wheel to wheel) so there is no sense of "i want to reach x rank" and it really defeats the motivation of playing online and makes online really weird putting top 1000 drivers vs newbies, 125 hours ish maybe to finish all the races and story with some messing around)*no modding community here, it's not supportedWHICH ONE TO BUY?buy the standard edition if your not really into cars and just want a nice looking and fun simple racing game that's not NFSDONT BUY THE DELUXE EDITION IT'S NOT WORTH IT, if u want the car pass chances are you are going to benefit from the stuff in the premium editionbuy the premium if u are a forza nerd/ petrolhead/  want a less realistic assetto corsal/ likes mexico/ want a more realistic nfs/ want to cruise around in your dream car with friends/ want to make liveries and mod cars

author: Exception
review: IF this is your first Forza horizon this game is great,But as a returning player it various This game just feels hollow.As someone who started with FH2 and bought the rest every release this launch is probably the most disappointing out of the 4 horizon games ive played.In my 80+ hours playing none of them have really stuck it feels like their is so much to do but so little incentive to do it.Past games felt rewarding with each hour you snuck in grinding cr for a car you have always wanted or meeting randoms and becoming friends doing random drives or hanging out and talking about almost everyones common interest of cars.The game starts you off with 3 CARS more then any other forza. it gifts you cars left and right making every reward feel that less impactful. it try to lure you in with the promise of how many vheicals their are. but half of them are in rotation and the only way you can get them is auction house or making sure you are grinding each week for the playlist cars. and forzashop is such a drag cars cost so much points compared to there reward at the end of an event,And with forzathon events being based on randoms coming together to help eachother complete the challenge this game sure as hell cant do that or even have the main feature and draw of the forza horizon games being openworld multiplayer right or working.The steam version is the superior pc port but is by far the WORST for multiplayer. the game is stable and runs great but i dont even have words for how frustrating it is to do anything with friends on xbox or W10 version which is still 70% of its playerbase. just nothing works, Invites,Lobbys,No-Ranked even though they copy and pasted FH4 modes no thought in any of the online tracks or how they flow, no voice chat, no in game option to invite, no friends list to see crossplatform people. and why is it i buy this game on steam and have to connect my xbox account to it just for it to say i dont own the game on xbox or WIN10 which means i cant invite people through xbox app or accept invites from someone on xbox or WIN10 LIKE WHY!!!!!! I WANNA PLAY WITH NEW PEOPLE BUT YOU MAKE IT SO â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ HARD TO DO SO.Other then that performance wise and graphics this game does great, And playing with a sim i do give props this games feels really good to control compared to past titles.

author: EmseyJay
review: Forza Horizon 5, is all about cars, your character's life revolves around cars, racing, and gaining a reputation. If you have played the previous, Forza Horizon 3 & 4. You know what's up ;) But for those of you who are stepping first hand into Forza, here's a bit about it:You are a well known racer, known for being able to drive really well, and gain a reputation. You can collect cars of a variety of brands, from Super cars, Rally cars, and even your Every day sort of cars. But with these cars you can customise them to your liking! You can design your own vinyl logos/designs, give it a new paint job, and even on the mechanical side of things, 'mod' your car to improve certain performances. Then, there's the fun part, Racing! Forza Horizon 5 is based in Mexico, where you can explore a wide range races, street races, dirt races, rally, etc. But then there's the Open World part. The world is stunning! Based on real sights seen in Mexico, with stunning details, graphics, sounds, and a whole open world to explore. You can play solo, or with friends, challenge your friends to races, or just mess around and drive Super Cars off the side of a Mountain... Whatever floats your boat really. In Short, I recommend this game to those who are interested in cars, racing, or just having a blast with some friends. And for those previous Forza Horizon players, if you don't have this game yet, What Are You Doing? ;) Hope this helped.

author: Rolpack
review: Played it for a while, done 80% of the things there is to do in this game, which means i mainly would want to play online races against other people, but they don't give you the choice to choose what type of races you want to play online, so you either keep lobby hopping over and over hoping you get a road race, or rally race, whichever you prefer, and you either get "lucky" after 30 minutes of hopping or you join in for the last race out of the 3 and get forced to a different lobby.TL;DR Can't choose what type of race you wanna play online, and theres little reason to keep playing the game after you completed most things that gets plastered on your in-game map.EDIT: They added custom racing, so now you can choose what you wanna race, but the lobbies are always dead for some reason.20mil players btw

author: SUPER SHADÃƒO
review: This game slowly broke my heart.I've been a player since Horizon 1, my expectations were as low as it possibly could, let's be honest here, there are no racing games out there, apart from a few elitist sims that are just inaccessible fancier racing games for people to sink money into (which i'm guilty myself of), racing games for you to kick back with a pad and play are very dead, your only options being the subpar console exclusive gran turismo, far disconnected from its glory days, the NFS series which had a good entry, followed by a cancellation and a painfully cringeworthy, ADD hellscape of a grind simulator sequel.All I wanted was a mediocre, bare minimum experience to fill that empty niche, and SOMEHOW, Horizon 5 manages to disappoint.Are the physics bad? No, not really, are the graphics and sound bad? they aren't great, but are half decent enough, how is the gameplay? Really not bad.So, what's wrong with it? Literally everything else, game stability is lacking, netplay is horrendous, the UI isn't good, QOL changes were completely ignored and issues all the way back from Horizon 3 are still present, the online balancing and matchmaking are a joke AGAIN, the progression is nonexistent and modeled around player retention only.Let me walk you through the "content" of this game:1-Play through the core game, there are no real characters, duels, cutscenes, nothing, just sequences of races that unlock sequences of races, sure, i'm not expecting Racing Lagoon here or Mass Effect on wheels so I can vibe with that.2-After a dozen hours at most, finish most of the game's content, go see what else is there to do, find the blueprints and nothing else.From now on, that's it, you're stuck in a barren map, to replay the same races over and over again, you login every week, for a new season to start and a handful of new cars that the devs are holding over your head due to FOMO, god knows when they are making a comeback, so you don't want to miss them, right?You do a coop race that is everything but fun, the netplay is horrible, queues and loads take ages, the playerbase is more of a challenge than anything else the game can throw at you because they are SO BAD you'll need to win the race, and hold the bots back enough for the complete mentally challenged teammates to have a chance to pass, try that a couple times with a 12 minute interval between each 3 race stint and hope you get lucky eventually, then there are speedtraps, jumps and speedzones, for some reason mostly they are set to S2, the objectively worst class in the game and the goals are set so stupidly high, there is no point in trying them honestly, get a rimac or some unbalanced car, download an unbalanced setup and cheese them.Then there are championships, which are either a fun way to revisit some of the races with car restrictions and point system with the option of playing with a friend, or the absolute worst circuits you can muster with a car that should not be doing them, making it a frustrating mess.A little car specific challenge, which is usually fine, but sometimes takes a long, long grind to complete.And last and definitively least, treasure hunts and multiplayer challenges, the treasure hunts range from pathetically obvious to incoherent and the multiplayer...why would you even do that to yourself?If you have severe issues with masochism and enjoy having mental pain be inflicted on you, or if you are so desperate for validation that you're using meta knowledge to dunk on children to get a dopamine hit, you can play multiplayer.So what else is there to do? Nothing, nothing at all, zero, nil, nada.Wait for an underwhelming update that you'll play through in 45 minutes or a "DLC" that the devs will put minimal effort on. In a sidenote, how dare they release a "rally dlc"? Who wanted this? Who was this designed for? The offroad cars don't even have an offroad model, NO ONE enjoys cross country, why would you theme an entire DLC around the worst aspect of the game? This feels like a slap in the face and was the tipping point for me to give up on this game.On a final note, the community, the devs actively support cheaters, communities of cheaters and the support is done by incompetent, unfair and borderline criminal personel, there are so many outrageous incidents that I cannot get into or this will become a twenty page essay, look up on youtube a video called "The Dark Side of Modern Forza" made by SP4 if you're interested in the shady, borderline criminal activity the devs are engaged with.

author: TheSunIsFun
review: There used to be a huge issue with the game crashing while I was using a fanatec wheel, but it seems to have stopped crashing so I like this game. It feels great on the wheel, especially the drifting for me. I've been able to make some pretty fun cars that I actively enjoy using. I know a lot of people do not like the current state of the game and that's very fair. The cars people want to see or the customization people want, but if you want a forza game where you have the freedom of an open world and want something that feels great on wheel that isn't something like Assetto then I recommend this game.

review: same formula as forza horizon 4, but with the fun and world building mechanics of lego island DLC, better progression system, and the feel of red dead redemption 2 enivronmentally wise but with cars. most fun ive had in a really long time on a racing game since test drive unlimited 2. car handling feels awesome all around.

author: Helix (sav)
review: I'll keep this review simple for all who don't want to read an overly detailed essay.Forza Horizon 5 (FH5) is a major step up from Forza Horizon 4 (FH4). It extends and excels in many of the areas that FH4 was lacking. Such as the map, the car sounds, the graphics, and the overall detail this is apparent in every corner of the game. Being a major Forza series fan, I went into this game with my expectations held high. And boy was I not disappointed. Although the game is still rough around the edges, the sheer love and care that went into the game is simply breath taking. Everything from the scenery, ambience, diversity and cars. The game has taken every detail into account to the point that it actually feels like its own world. Cruising around the jungle quite literally feels like you are in a real jungle, with the intricate and realistic ambience that encompasses you while you play. One of the biggest changes implemented in FH5 is the change in breaking and suspension physics. Although very noticeable at first, both me and everyone I know prefer it, as it provides a slightly more realistic, yet easy-to-use driving style. It makes each car feel more stable and whole, allowing them to have more give, and ultimately more feedback. This paired with the amazingly detailed world (in looks and sound) means that driving around the FH5 map actually seems like you're going on a modern day cruise in your own 1 of 20 hyper car through the Mexican Desert. Something that FH4 was lacking. Each car looks, sounds and feels like its own beast, waiting to be unleashed. FH5 has captured an essence of open world car games that I feel FH4 never had. Emotion.

author: Maddin
review: Game kept crashing at the same point after the tutorial. Right before where I get to make my character. 9 or so times it crashed, reinstalled (hours to get the 100gig down again), tried everything. Fresh reboot did it (e.g turning off EVERY SINGLE AUTOSTART PROGRAM). Got it working. Played for 6 hours, had a blast, made good progress. Outbid someone for a Aston Martin Vulcan. Upgraded it to X class 999. Tuned it to my liking. real happy about it. Went to sleep. Woke up and EVERYTHING IS GONE. Back to the FORCED CUTSCENE Tutorial for the 10th time. 10/10 as a racing game, which it is for most. BUT 0/10 as the roguelite I've gotten somehow.

author: saltiestgamer
review: I have supported the Forza franchise since the first release on the original Xbox. I have been increasingly disappointed since Horizon 3. Horizon 5 is the result of development team becoming complacent with past successes...Horizon 5 is not a polished game and has many problems that still exist AFTER several patches have been pushed out.Buy at your own risk. Horizon 5 is in a somewhat playable state on my Alienware Area 51-m Laptop. Horizon 5 does not work reliably on my custom desktop. Horizon 5 is an unfinished product that they clearly couldn't afford to finish without our investment post release.I will be returning Horizon 5 until it is discounted substantially.

author: Genus
review: Obviously not, the perfect game does not exist.We have grown familiar with the big AAA Releases that seem to promise everything we ever wanted and then under deliver or ship a game that is riddled with bugs. Forza Horizon 5 is close to fitting in with the rest of these games, what saves it is the solid foundation that playground games has build over the last couple of years and the reputation of the studio itself.Forza Horizon 5 does not break any boundaries or revolutionizes the way you look at racing games. It does the same things the previous entries where known for (for better or for worse). The handling has improved while still having the simcade feeling most fans want from a Forza Horizon game, the car list is ever expanding and the graphics have been upgraded once more.The big gripe I have with this game is that these improvements all feel expected, what came as a surprise where the bugs that plague the game since launch. Especially the multiplayer feels incomplete and buggy. Long loading times between races and random disconnects from the online features. Try completing a Forza Arcade Event... you can't, most of the time. This might seem like I am not happy with the game. Then why do I recommend it?Playground games has proven that, different to other AAA Developers, they care about their games. I am quite confident that all the gripes I have will be addressed and that the game will change over time like the previous entry.For Fans of the Forza Horizon franchise it's a must buy, everyone else should wait for the first sale or the release of more content through the planned dlc.

author: ð“¹ð–†ð“¿ð“¼
review: Fellas... Fellas. Let me tell you about this messy masterpiece.Before you purchase, you have to realise that you are looking at a racing arcade that has just recently released.Along with a whole list of disappointments:- Where the hell is Alfa Romeo, Abarth, Lancia, realy all cars missing from past FH titles (F licencing)- Similarity between some race tracks in separate categories- A s*** ton of bugs ofc- Controller DLC does not apply to Steam purchase... wth MicrosoftOkay, okay now there are a "couple" points that tend to impress:- OOOh MY LORD! The graphics are top f****** notch- Lots of past "rare" cars are now in the Autoshow for purchase- Big improvements on engine sounds along with "revving" in the upgrade menu, big ass thumbs up- Massive map, almost as massive as Elon Musk's prefrontal cortex- Access to over 500 different cars, and a Willie's JeepThere is honestly a lot to appreciate about this title and it is also on Xbox game pass, if you're into that...Game do be buggy asf dough

author: Jinoyoko Fusunshi
review: In general it's a awesome game for longtime races, as for new ones too.I have never played any Forza title before this one, but when I saw a lot of videos and promotions from this game I got really hyped in the beginning. So I gave it a try and to my surprise my excitement and hype to play this game hasn't turned me down since the day I bought it.You are driving through a beautiful scene of Mexico and you're all busy to do any challenge, any race, any modification or visual changes on your car. The game had an strong beginning and actually held my excitment by receiving new cars, going through the story with funny attractions, new challenges and different types of races very stable. It gives you many opportnunities how you wanna play gameplay wise, such as if you wanna play alone or with other racers from the community, on which difficulty when you are alone, which kind of activity in general you wann do on the whole map in Mexico and much more.For people who like a more hyperactive atmosphere through the story and likes to tune and collect many cars as possible through honest work definitely worth playing!

author: Dahlerino
review: The game is just gorgeous..The plus is a beautifully crafted map with tons and tons of details, it doesnt just feel empty or Ctrl C -> Ctrl V everywhere.The cars handling and sounds are amazing too.You can really feel the weight of some cars in street races (Big exception for the Sesto Elemento FE. It's just built different)One of the many problems this game has is it's Mini stories... The writing and dialouge in them are so... Childish?And the spanglish forced into every single sentence is so annoying.If you like racing games or just cars in general i highly recommend you try this game out as it has a lot to offer. Street races, Dirt races, offroad and you can just pick whatever car you want and go with it everywhere.

author: Joshua Norton
review: I really recommend this game for anyone looking for a casual'ish, relaxing racing game that neither demands you to have knowledge of specific details about cars nor that you have an extraordinary driving skill.it can be as relaxis as it can be competitive and exiting and with lots of setting-options for difficulty and driving behavior, i think it fits most people...or rather most people can make it fit their taste and liking, especially since you are able to adjust everything constantly.this isnt a gran tourismo or asetto corsa nor is it a mario kart but its a mix between those which i personally really enjoy.the cars feel realistic enough while driving, unless you create ridiculous tunings and go off-road with a sports car, but thats fun in itself.one downside is that most features are locked behind an online-demand, which is a downside but also nothing new to forza horizon.regarding performance, its pretty impressive how well this game runs with the graphics it provides as well as how big the world is, although there currently are issues with textures not loading sometimes or really slowly(for some walls, gates and so on).otherwise, these devs really put some techno-magick to work here.the mexico-inspired world looks great and has several different biomes, which add a very enjoyable variety, unlike the pretty bland world that was forza horizon 4's england-inspired map, so this is a big plus in my books(also, finally driving on the proper side of the road, ffs :p).just one advice, it can be *very* grindy as you can unlock *a lot* of stuff, there is weekly "seasonal"-events to unlock vehicles which the game states are "rare" or "hard to get" which could lure you into grinding sessions but keep in mind those vehicles will not show up for only one such weekly events but several times a year.other unlock-mechanics such as "wheelspins" which are essentially loot-boxes(although completely free!) add to that grinding urge and being constantly rewarding with experience points for literally *everything* you do will add to that as well.just keep in mind that you are not loosing out on anything if you take a slow approach to unlocking things, this game will be around for a while for you to fully enjoy.

author: The Lynx Im
review: Outstanding SOLO racing sim/arcade. If you wanna play alone, this is the game for you. I recommend it.BUT it is not a frickin solo game, is it? I DO NOT recommend it if you want to play with friends or family. The moment you decide to do so the game turns into a Loading Sim and if by some fluke in the fabric of reality you connect to each other you can make 1 (ONE) race and then the whole thing starts again. Out of my 104 hours so far me and my friends have played TOGETHER maybe about 20 hours. And we continue trying to play because there is nothing else to play of the sort. (Can't wait for TDU Solar crown)If you want to play with other non friends or family people online, the game turns into a Bumper car Sim. The option to create custom adventures or whatever they call it in this version #5 is GONE. No more no-collision or custom class racing.I mean what THE FRICKIN HELL Turn10? Its like you copy-paste all bugs from horizon 1 forward and any improvements you made you delete and get a brand new team to design and program the game from scratch+the above mentioned bugs.I have been a loyal Forza fan for years and have played all games since Forza motorsport 1 to present. I was disappointed in FH4 and after this one I dont think I will buy any Forza ever.The game is basically in alpha so do not buy it at full price and definitely dont buy the premium version. The game doesnt have too many hours of solo gameplay (about 20 maybe more if you go for all accolades and achievements) and with the premium you will halve that.
